title: why the reporting/ban system will never be fair!
body:
its as simple as i am guys.

the reports are only taken seriously when atleast 2 or more people report.
regaurdless if you are right or wrong, the bans work in favour of how many ppl reported said person.
pretty simple huh? so gang up wit ur mates and report everyone!!!

viva la revolution

replies.body:
> the reports are only taken seriously when atleast 2 or more people report.
regaurdless if you are right or wrong, the bans work in favour of how many ppl reported said person.

I'm happy to shed some light on this.

It only takes 1 report for a game to be reviewed. Punishments (for verbal types) are based entirely on the contents of YOUR chat.

Getting reports beyond 1 does not increase the chance or speed of a game being reviewed. So, the next time you encounter that player spewing off hate speech, just mute them and report them after. There is no reason to ask other players to report them.

Hey Tantram, I think I was wrongfully chat restricted. I had a bad game and my teammates were bashing me all game long, even the other team was sitting there flaming me, I don't think I was in the wrong for being pushed to that kind of anger, they instigated me to that and I don't think its quite fair for me to be chat restricted for being pushed, I can't say I was in the wrong, and I hope you'd agree with me because being flamed isn't fun, and when everyone is doing it, it becomes an anger fest, thanks.

You are welcome to make a post and provide your chat logs. 

However, I did take a look and you were threatening to afk at 4 mins without any provocation because you didn't get a gank and were being held down. You then started in on the hate speech and harassment, and ended the game asking for the enemy team to report your teammates who were putting up with your behavior all game.

Please explain, please explain to me how they had to put up with me, please do that, you make no sense with that, why not give them chat restrictions too for what they did, the Nidalee and the Thresh both sitting there flaming the whole entire game, I don't know how that's my fault, also, I asked for a level 3 gank, I was angry, and she did nothing but feed the fire, so that's my fault? Please elaborate for me, please I beg of you.
Post the chat log, the community would love to explain it to you.

Someone else behaving poorly doesn't excuse your own poor behavior as well. If someone is acting up and they refuse to stop them just mute and report them instead of feeding the trolls so-to-speak. As for why you were punished first it's because you were already close to crossing the line and this game was the one that pushed you over that line so-to-speak there. If that other player continues to act up then they will eventually be punished as well just like you were here. From [Understanding the Tribunal](http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=2726400): 

>**4) That player in my game was far worse than me. Why am I banned???**
a) I'll keep this one simple: retaliation isn't OK. Reacting to a toxic player by being toxic just incites that player to be even worse--it also ruins the game for up to 8 other players. It is far, far worse to watch two people yelling at each other all game than it is to watch 1 player ranting into blank space. Almost everyone in the game can find someone out there that behaves worse than they do--but so what? Finding someone worse doesn't justify your behavior or justify retaliation. We expect more out of our players. What players often don't realize is... those other players in your game that you thought were worse? Nearly 100% of the time, those players were banned even before you were. If someone is being toxic, just report them and move on. If you retaliate, both of you will be banned. It's really that simple.

Now if you want to actually discuss your punishment then please post your entire unedited Reform Card here for us to see (check your email/spam folder and the game client for it: the email contains one game while the game client can contain up to three).

Your behavior is your fault. If you choose to react in a way that the League community does not consider acceptable, you need to figure out how to change that if you want to stay a part of this community.

He did: "you were threatening to afk at 4 mins" | "You then started in on the hate speech and harassment." That's not something *I'd* want to have to put up with in game. 

There may have been mitigating circumstances, but that doesn't matter: the actions of allies do not excuse your actions, as Riot has said many times. The option to mute them, or to not respond and simply read the chat, or the option to simply respond with in-game information and keep your anger out of the game chat are all possible, and if you choose to engage on a toxic level it is your decision, no matter WHAT the other players may or may not have done.

We have the parallel in real life. If you engage with someone causing a Disturbance of the Peace in an equally aggressive manner, you can ALSO be cited for a Disturbance of the Peace, even if they "started it." Since it was no direct threat to you you had the option to not engage them -- you can't cite "self defense" in these situations unless there was some actual tangible danger to your person.

Whether you were provoked or not, you still lowered yourself to that level and fired back. The best way to deal with it is to ignore them completely.

Letting your emotions take over and drown your rational thoughts is never a good thing. I made the decision years ago to never let anger control my actions. If I type something, it's only after examining my emotional state and making the conscious decision to send the message.

No, there's no need to remove a feature just because a select few choose to abuse it in a negative fashion. Riot's stance has always been to remove the people who abuse features to be jerks rather than the actual features themselves. If someone can't or won't control themselves enough to not constantly take the time to type out rage filled posts in the chat then that's on them, not Riot.

Also, your analogy doesn't work in this case since the people in question often know what will happen if they negatively abuse features constantly and just don't care. Riot doesn't punish people who use features in-game, they punish those who use them to constantly create a negative environment for those around them instead. If chatting is an issue for you then just move the chat box to where it's no longer visible to you on your screen.

>without them muted, because I was trying to be a team player

This has always seemed a weak argument to me. In my experience, players who are so negative in chat that I feel compelled to mute them will rarely, if ever, say anything relevant to the game itself in chat. They're too busy raging for that.

Yes, you might run into an exception to this now and then. But I think the benefits of muting these people far outweigh the risks, especially if you know you're prone to being set off by things people say in the chat.

Sure, I'll believe that only a single report gets a game reviewed. But it just wouldn't make sense for multiple reports not to be taken into consideration for weight of severity outside of premades ganging up. If all other 9 players in the game reported you, you probly did something more screwed up than if only one player or one premade reported you.

While many reports in a single match increase the chance of the system reviewing their case, premade groups only have the weight of a single report no matter how many of them do it. It only takes one report to flag a match for review, so if they continue their negative behavior and are consistently reported even by just one solo player, they'll get reviewed and all the matches will count just the same.

If you were punished, feel free to post the chat logs if you'd like to discuss it with the community. If you think your ban was an error, then you can contest it by submitting a [Support Ticket](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/requests/new).

> many reports in a single match increase the chance of the system reviewing their case

Wait, what's your source for this statement? I've never read anything except "one report = enough for review" from Riot sources*, such as @RiotTantram in this thread.

Then you also say, "It only takes one report to flag a match for review" - so what exactly did you mean in the first sentence?

*_except, "players who consistently make false reports against others diminishes the value of that player's report and renders them meaningless" - but that seems irrelevant here_

The confusion is likely because reviews do not happen every time someone makes a report. One report is enough to flag a match, and when a review does happen it's going to get checked no matter what (which is what Tantram is saying). If the system does do a case review *every single time* a report is made, then Tantram needs to clear that up with the Player Support staff because I get my information directly from them when I need it.

That clears up your comment, thanks.

Just to be clear, Tantram said
> Getting reports beyond 1 does not increase the chance or speed of a game being reviewed.

This does directly contradict the idea that "many reports in a single match increase the chance of the system reviewing their case," even if there is a delay between a flag and a review.

You're always helpful and accurate on the boards, DTN, and I appreciate it; this misconception is just a major pet peeve!
I knew that speed and chanche of review increase with *number of games* reported, instead of number of reports. Which makes sense to me.

Sorry but that's not how it works. One report is as good as nine reports, and multiple reports won't get someone punished any faster than one report would, especially if the reports in question are false. If you get punished then it's because you were consistently showing poor behavior across multiple games and refused to stop.

Technically, more reports in a single match *can* trigger a review faster, just not premade reports. Worse behavior tends to get more reports per match, so it helps get the worst offenders off the Rift faster.
